standard_metadata.standard_description: Decompose a fraction into a sum of fractions with the same denominator in more than one way, recording each decomposition by an equation. Justify decompositions, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.

hints.content: First, let's visualize $\dfrac{6}{3}$.  [[☃ image 1]]  Now, let's compare each answer choice to $\dfrac{6}{3}$.

images.alt: Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 3 equal parts, each part labeled one-third. A curved bracket below both fraction bars is labeled six-thirds.

Two sets of equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. The first set has two fraction bars that are each divided into 2 equal parts and each part is labeled one-half. A curved bracket above the first set of fraction bars is labeled four-halves. The second set has two fraction bars that are whole and labeled 1 over 1. A curved bracket above the second set of fraction bars is labeled 2 over 1. Together the curved brackets above the fraction bars are labeled four-halves plus 2 over 1.
Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 3 equal parts, each part labeled one-third. A curved bracket below both fraction bars is labeled six-thirds.

Three equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 3 equal parts, each part labeled one-third. A curved bracket above the first bar and two parts of the second bar is labeled five-thirds. A curved bracket above the remaining part of the second bar is labeled one-third. A curved bracket above two parts of the third bar is labeled two-thirds. A curved bracket above the remaining part of the third bar is labeled one-third. Together the curved brackets above the fraction bars are labeled five-thirds plus one-third plus two-thirds plus one-third.
Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 3 equal parts, each part labeled one-third. A curved bracket below both fraction bars is labeled six-thirds.

Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 3 equal parts, each part labeled one-third. A curved bracket above the first 2 parts of the first bar is labeled two-thirds. A curved bracket above the remaining part of the first bar and the first part of the second bar is labeled two-thirds. A curved bracket above the remaining 2 parts of the second bar is labeled two-thirds. Together the curved brackets above the fraction bars are labeled two-thirds plus two-thirds plus two-thirds.
Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 3 equal parts, each part labeled one-third. A curved bracket below both fraction bars is labeled six-thirds.

hints.content: First, let's visualize $\dfrac{20}{5}$.    [[☃ image 1]]  Now, let's compare each answer choice to $\dfrac{20}{5}$.

images.alt: Four equal-sized fraction bars set in a row. Each fraction bar is divided into 5 equal parts, each part labeled one-fifth. A curved bracket below all of the fraction bars is labeled twenty-fifths.

Five equal-sized fraction bars set in a row. Each fraction bar is divided into 5 equal parts, each part labeled one-fifth. In the first fraction bar, a curved bracket above the first two parts is labeled two-fifths. A curved bracket above the last three parts in the first bar and the first part of the second bar is labeled four-fifths. A curved bracket above the last four parts of the second bar and the first two parts of the third bar is labeled six-fifths. A curved bracket over the last three parts of the third bar, the entire fourth bar, and the first two parts of the fifth bar is labeled ten-fifths. Together the curved brackets above the fraction bars are labeled two-fifths plus four-fifths plus six-fifths plus ten-fifths.
Four equal-sized fraction bars set in a row. Each fraction bar is divided into 5 equal parts, each part labeled one-fifth. A curved bracket below all of the fraction bars is labeled twenty-fifths.

Two sets of equal-sized fraction bars set side-by-side. The first set has five fraction bars that are each divided into 3 equal parts and each part is labeled one-third. A curved bracket above the first set of fraction bars is labeled fifteen-thirds. The second set has three fraction bars that are each divided into 2 equal parts and each part is labeled one-half. A curved bracket above the first and second bars and the first part of the third bar is labeled five-halves. Together the curved brackets above the fraction bars are labeled fifteen-thirds plus five-halves.
Four equal-sized fraction bars set in a row. Each fraction bar is divided into 5 equal parts, each part labeled one-fifth. A curved bracket below all of the fraction bars is labeled twenty-fifths.

Four equal-sized fraction bars set in a row. Each fraction bar is divided into 5 equal parts, each part labeled one-fifth. A curved bracket above the first bar and the first three parts of the second bar is labeled eight-fifths. A curved bracket above the last two parts of the second bar and the first three parts of the third bar is labeled five-fifths. A curved bracket above the last two parts of the third bar and the entire fourth bar is labeled seven-fifths. Together the curved brackets above the bar are labeled eight-fifths plus five-fifths plus seven-fifths.
Four equal-sized fraction bars set in a row. Each fraction bar is divided into 5 equal parts, each part labeled one-fifth. A curved bracket below all of the fraction bars is labeled twenty-fifths.

images.alt: Two-equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 8 equal parts, each part labeled one-eighth. A curved bracket below both fraction bars is labeled sixteen-eighths.

A curved bracket above the first two parts of the first bar is labeled two-eighths. A curved bracket above the remaining parts of the first bar and the first four parts of the second bar is labeled ten-eighths. A curved bracket above the next three parts of the second bar is labeled three-eighths. A curved bracket above the last part of the second bar and the first part of the third bar is labeled two-eighths. Together, the curved brackets are labeled two-eighths plus ten-eighths plus three-eighths plus two eighths.
Two-equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 8 equal parts, each part labeled one-eighth. A curved bracket below both fraction bars is labeled sixteen-eighths.

Two sets of equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. The first set has two fraction bars that are each divided into 6 equal parts and each part is labeled one-sixth. A curved bracket above the first set of fraction bars is labeled twelve-sixths. The second set has two fraction bars that are each divided into 2 equal parts and each part is labeled one-half. A curved bracket above the second set of fraction bars is labeled four-halves. Together the curved brackets are labeled twelve-sixths plus four-halves.
Two-equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 8 equal parts, each part labeled one-eighth. A curved bracket below both fraction bars is labeled sixteen-eighths.

Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 8 equal parts, each part labeled one-eighth. A curved bracket above the first five parts of the first bar is labeled five-eighths. A curved bracket over the remaining parts of the first bar and the first two parts of the second bar is labeled five-eighths. A curved bracket over the next five parts of the second bar is labeled five-eighths. A curved bracket over the last part of the second bar is labeled one-eighth. Together the curved brackets are labeled five-eights plus five-eighths plus five-eighths plus one-eighth.
Two-equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 8 equal parts, each part labeled one-eighth. A curved bracket below both fraction bars is labeled sixteen-eighths.

hints.content: First, let's visualize $\dfrac{5}{6}$.    [[☃ image 1]]  Now, let's compare each answer choice to $\dfrac{5}{6}$.

images.alt: A fraction bar divided into 6 equal parts, each part labeled one-sixth. A curved bracket below the first five parts is labeled five-sixths.

A fraction bar divided into 6 equal parts, each part labeled one-sixth. A curved bracket above the first three parts is labeled three-sixths. A curved bracket over the fourth part is labeled one-sixth. A curved bracket over the remaining parts is labeled two-sixths. Together the curved brackets are labeled three-sixths plus one-sixth plus two-sixths.
A fraction bar divided into 6 equal parts, each part labeled one-sixth. A curved bracket below the first five parts is labeled five-sixths.

A fraction bar divided into 6 equal parts, each part labeled one-sixth. A curved bracket above the first four parts is labeled four-sixths. A curved bracket above the fifth part is labeled one-sixth. Together the curved brackets are labeled four-sixths plus one-sixth.

A curved bracket above the fourth part is labeled one-sixth. A curved bracket above the fifth part is labeled one-sixth. A fraction bar divided into 6 equal parts, each part labeled one-sixth. A curved bracket below the first five parts is labeled five-sixths.

hints.content: All of the fractions have the same denominator, $2$, so the parts have the same size. We are ready to add.

The numerators tell us how many parts we are counting. We want $13$ equal parts.  $\blueD{1}+\greenD{4}+\purpleD{8}=13$    [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac{1}{2}}+\greenD{\dfrac{4}{2}} +\purpleD{\dfrac{8}{2}} =\dfrac{13}{2}$

images.alt: Seven fraction bars set in a row. Each fraction bar is divided into 2 equal parts and each part is labeled one-half. A curved bracket above the first part of the first fraction bar is labeled one-half. A curved bracket over the remaining part of the first fraction bar, all the parts of the second fraction bar, and the first part of the third fraction bar is labeled four-halves. A curved bracket over the remaining part of the third fraction bar, all of the parts of the fourth, fifth, and sixth fraction bars, and the first part of the seventh fraction bar is labeled eight-halves. Together the curved brackets are labeled one-half plus four-halves plus eight-halves. A curved bracket below the first six fraction bars and the first part of the seventh fraction bar is labeled thirteen-halves.

hints.content: All of the fractions have the same denominator, $4$, so the parts have the same size. We are ready to add.
The numerators tell us how many parts we are counting. We want $10$ equal parts.  $\blueD{8}+\greenD{2}=10$   [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac{8}{4}}+\greenD{\dfrac{2}{4}}  =\dfrac{10}{4}$

images.alt: Three equal-sized fraction bars set in a row. Each fraction bar is divided into 4 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-fourth. A curved bracket above all parts in the first and second fraction bars is labeled eight-fourths. A curved bracket above the first two parts of the third fraction bar is labeled two-fourths. Together the curved brackets above the fraction bars are labeled eight-fourths plus two-fourths. A curved bracket below the first two fraction bars and the first two parts of the third fraction bar is labeled ten-fourths.

hints.content: All of the fractions have the same denominator, $5$, so the parts have the same size. We are ready to add.

The numerators tell us how many parts we are counting. We want $11$ equal parts.  $\blueD{1}+\greenD{8} + \purpleD2=11$   [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac{1}{5}}+\greenD{\dfrac{8}{5}}  + \purpleD{\dfrac{2}{5}}=\dfrac{11}{5}$

images.alt: Three equal-sized fraction bars set in a row. Each fraction bar is divided into 5 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-fifth. A curved bracket above the first part of the first fraction bar is labeled one-fifth. A curved bracket over the last four parts of the first fraction bar and the first four parts of the second fraction bar is labeled eight-fifths. A curved bracket above the last part of the second fraction bar and the first part of the third fraction bar is labeled two-fifths. Together, the curved brackets above the fraction bar are labeled one-fifth plus eight-fifths plus two-fifths. A curved bracket below the first and second fraction bars and the first part of the third fraction bar is labeled eleven-fifths.

hints.content: All of the fractions have the same denominator, $3$, so the parts have the same size. We are ready to add.

The numerators tell us how many parts we are counting. We want $7$ equal parts.  $\blueD{1}+\greenD{4} + \purpleD2=7$    [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac{1}{3}}+\greenD{\dfrac{4}{3}}  + \purpleD{\dfrac{2}{3}}=\dfrac{7}{3}$

images.alt: Three equal-sized fraction bars set in a row. Each fraction bar is divided into three equal parts, and each part is labeled one-third. A curved bracket above the first part of the first fraction bar is labeled one-third. A curved bracket above the remaining parts of the first fraction bar and the first two parts of the second fraction bar is labeled four-thirds. A curved bracket above the last part of the second fraction bar and the first part of the third fraction bar is labeled two-thirds. Together the curved brackets above the fraction bars are labeled one-third plus four-thirds plus two-thirds. A curved bracket below the first and second fraction bars and the first part of the third fraction bars is labeled seven-thirds.

hints.content: All of the fractions have the same denominator, $6$, so the parts have the same size. We are ready to add.
The numerators tell us how many parts we are counting. We want $3$ equal parts.  $\blueD{1}+\greenD{2}=3$    [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac{1}{6}}+\greenD{\dfrac{2}{6}}  =\dfrac{3}{6}$

images.alt: A fraction bar divided into 6 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-sixth. A curved bracket above the first part is labeled one-sixth. A curved bracket above the next two parts is labeled two-sixths. Together the curved brackets above the fraction bar are labeled one-sixth plus two-sixths. A curved bracket below the first three parts of the fraction bar is labeled three-sixths.

hints.content: All of the fractions have the same denominator, $8$, so the parts have the same size. We are ready to add.
The numerators tell us how many parts we are counting. We want $5$ equal parts.  $\blueD{4}+\greenD{1}=5$    [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac{4}{8}}+\greenD{\dfrac{1}{8}}  =\dfrac{5}{8}$

images.alt: A fraction bar divided into 8 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-eighth. A curved bracket above the first four parts of the fraction bar is labeled four-eighths. A curved bracket above the next part is labeled one-eighth. Together the curved brackets above the fraction bar are labeled four-eighths plus one-eighth. A curved bracket below the first five parts of the fraction bar is labeled five-eighths.
